Author: dpapathanasiou
Content: But even Flash for Linux seems like a low priority -- the latest version (9?) for Linux was released long after the Windows and Mac versions were done.

Author: Agathos
Content: You may say the DMCA is a bad law. I'm inclined to agree. And if you choose to violate a bad law and risk the consequences, you'll be in some heroic company. But demanding that someone else, like Digg, violate the law and risk the consequences in your place seems a bit low.

Author: dpapathanasiou
Content:
I think it just reflects how hard it is to get attention these days.

I didn't mind it because it was fairly novel (mail we get to that address is usually either a feature request or a user complaint), and seemed legit.

But if tons of other groups start advertising their events this way, it could get tiring, fast.

Author: Goladus
Content: Why they think Friendster failed: the mostly non-technical board of directors did lots of bone-headed things.

Author: BrandonM
Content: I've been looking for a reason to leave Chase ever since they bought out Bank One.  I had no problems with Bank One, banking with them for several years.  I then got a credit card with Chase that was attached to my checking account, and after one payment that was a day late, they raised my APR from 0% (intro) to 24%.  Calling them and mentioning that I had been a long-time customer did no good.  Now that I've paid off the card and seen this submission, I'm at the point where I'm ready to end my associations with Chase altogether.

Author: BrandonM
Content:
So the lesson is that every single developer should rewrite all of their complicated code (the code which uses closures and circular referencing) so that the major browser developers can avoid writing a good GC algorithm?

It reminded me of this story from the Jargon File:\nhttp://www.catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/koans.html#id3141202

So we should believe that browser developers are no more advanced than students from the 70s?

Author: create_account
Content:
So you control the entire server as root, you get 1 TB of bandwidth, and it's $50 a month?

Wow, that's the best combination so far... they do skimp on RAM and HD size, compared to some of the others.

Is it too good to be true? What disadvantages or problems have other people seen?

Author: create_account
Content:
But will they open source it, like Adobe did with Flex?

Making it cross-platform (in the short term) is a great strategy, because then, if it gains acceptance, they can force you back on Windows in the long run (assuming it stays closed during that time span).
